The prostate gland is composed of glandular tissue and stroma. There are focal areas of adenocarcinoma within the glands. The adenocarcinoma cells are relatively uniform in size and shape. No evidence of metastasis is identified.

**Comments:**
The Gleason score of 7 indicates a moderately aggressive prostate cancer. This type of cancer can be treated effectively with surgery or radiation therapy. Further evaluation may be needed depending on the patient's overall health and specific characteristics of the tumor.

**Recommendations:**
1. Discuss treatment options with your urologist.

The dermal infiltrate is composed of atypical melanocytes infiltrating the dermis and extending into the subcutaneous fat. The neoplastic melanocytes exhibit variability in size and shape, with some cells showing irregular nuclear contours and prominent nucleoli. Perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate is noted.

**Diagnosis:**
Basal cell carcinoma, ulcerated type.

**Comments:**
The diagnosis is based on the presence of a basaloid proliferation with dermal and subcutaneous extension, atypical mitoses, and infiltrating atypical melanocytes.

**Pathologist Signature:** Dr. Smith

The liver is enlarged, measuring 20 cm in length. There is diffuse yellow-brown discoloration. The cut surface shows a heterogeneous appearance with areas of fibrosis, fatty infiltration, and focal nodular hyperplasia. A 3 cm mass is identified in the right lobe.

**Microscopic Description:**
The liver parenchyma shows marked steatosis and portal inflammation. There is bridging fibrosis extending to the central vein in several areas. The portal tracts contain bile duct proliferation and portal edema. The lobules demonstrate extensive hepatocyte necrosis and regeneration. A 3 cm mass is identified in the right lobe, composed of poorly differentiated malignant hepatocytes with extensive necrosis and vascular invasion. The tumor cells are positive for Hep Par 1, AFP, and CK20. The surrounding liver tissue shows chronic inflammation and fibrosis.

**Comments:**
The liver biopsy is consistent with chronic hepatitis C, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma. The HCC is moderately differentiated.

**Patient:** John Doe
**Age:** 65
**Sex:** Male
**Date of Report:** 2023-10-27
**Specimen:** Biopsy, Liver
**Diagnosis:** Chronic hepatitis C, cirrhosis with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC)

**Gross Description:**
A 10x10x5 cm piece of liver tissue. The cut surface is yellow-tan, firm, and lobulated. There is a 4x4x3 cm nodule in the right lobe, which is tan-white and firm. There is also a smaller 2x2x1 cm nodule in the left lobe. The remaining liver tissue shows diffuse yellow discoloration and coarse fibrosis.

**Microscopic Description:**
The liver parenchyma shows marked chronic inflammation with portal fibrosis and bridging fibrosis. There is evidence of hepatocellular necrosis and regeneration. A 4x4x3 cm nodule in the right lobe is composed of atypical hepatocytes with enlarged nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and increased mitotic activity. These cells are arranged in trabecular patterns and cords, with intervening fibrous stroma. There is a 2x2x1 cm nodule in the left lobe showing similar features of atypical hepatocytes with necrosis and regeneration. The surrounding liver tissue shows mild portal inflammation and fibrosis.

**Comments:**
The findings are consistent with chronic hepatitis C, cirrhosis with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
